Do not buy this if you plan on plugging it into a Windows computer to access data, or load movies, books, whatever.  I have tried using this on several computers ranging from Windows 10, 8.1 and 7.  Support was very short with me and simply stated that the Android device is not compatible with ANY version of Windows.

This truly amazing laptop does it all, if you are in the business of revenge and dirty deeds.

After reading reviews here and on other sites, it became apparent that this device was crafted by a team of extremely fiendish gremlins and evil faeries. The sheer volume of people that became frustrated with the operation of this device only confirmed my observations.

I ordered this device for family members and people at work that I truly disliked, I even got one for our back up baby sitter that always denied using our children's iPads.

The effects were magically delicious: complaints, profanity, dismay at being unable to return or sell the device. Our targets of disdain were literally stuck with these cursed devices in a perpetual quandary of not wanting to use the exasperating object and the inability to give away, let alone sell, the vexing piece of tech.

If you're looking to cause someone some additional stress or to lose whatever hair they have left, order them a dozen...

Edit: I find the commenters taking this obvious sarcasm seriously to be quite delicious.

If you want a small device that will be consistantly inconsistant, this is the perfect device for you! Try typing a search request. You will be constantly amazed at how only a small part of what you typed will appear on the screen! Then, with only that small part, the device will usually switch you to a completely new, unrequested screen,  or make the cursor disappear. Sometimes other things will happen.

I have struggled with this crazy device for only two days, and already this morning I find that I have a strange twitch in my upper lip. My lip twitches only when I use this amazing device.

Would you like to stress someone out? Buy that person one of these RCA 10 Viking Pro devices! In only a few days, their demeanor will change.

Sent it back.

I purchased 5 of these in November, 2017, and they turned out to be perfect for my grand kid's school work.  They worked fine until August 3rd, 2018.  One went on the blink that day, and another one 'died' on the 5th.  Since they are within a year of purchase the manufacturer is responsible for repairs.  Talk about a joke?  I have filled out the 'repair/replace form three times this last week, and I have yet to receive anything except more instructions on filling out the 'repair/replace' form.  In fairness, I purchased them from another store, but they are the EXACT same thing!  I am old enough to remember when RCA was a top of the line, trusted producer of electronics, but that day is long gone.  Their piss-poor service is just adding insult to injury, IMHO

I got this product for my daughters to replace their old RCA that the screen happened to get busted on (mommy didn't see it under the covers and like Bigfoot stomped the screen on accident). We did the whole open package read the instructions and let it charge then they were off playing in it downloading this and that and watching you tube like normal. At the end of the day though it had lost completely all of its charge! The battery is obviously not very good at all! Very disappointing not only to them but to me as well. They weren't on it but I'd say 4 hours total all day. All of their other tablets have kept charge longer than that. Also noticed this morning that its already starting to bog down. I got on it to do the whole mom check and make sure nothing bad has been installed or viewed and it was already starting to take more than a couple seconds to load! They did download 8 games varying in sizes from ~20MB to the biggest ~90MB. There are no contacts, pictures, videos, or audios saved on this yet even! Good for the price. It's pretty inexpensive, so I'm giving it a break. The keyboard isn't bad, takes a little getting used to, but I have no complaints about it. The trackpad works well also.

My biggest complaint is that the battery is unpredictable. Sometimes it will be fine in stand-by for days, but other times, the battery will show nearly full, and I'll walk away for an hour and come back to it refusing to power on; the batter is now dead.

My second complaint is that it's a little slow. All I use it for is to view pdf documents and making notes using OneNote, I don't feel like that should tax the cpu much, but it does respond slowly sometimes.

Overall, it's a good buy for the price, but don't expect to have a replacement for your high-powered laptop here.

I originally bought one of these for my wife a couple days ago. It replaces her Android that slowed down after 4 years. I bought this from another major on-line site at $30 less. I fully understood, going into this tablet purchase it was a cheaper tablet.

Cons: It's thicker, even sans keyboard, then I would've liked. It feels cheap. Example being the power buttons wiggeled in the housing.

The main reason I went "Nope, sorry you're going back" was simply, during set up trying to put in the "draw your pattern" to lock it, took me five tries since it kept "disconnecting" my finger from the screen. Same with the "repeat pattern" then to throw out the three stock apps that I didn't want, took three tries to hold/drag to the trash bin.
I don't have any neurological issues that result in me not pressing/removing finger from tablet. So this was all on the screen side.
The inability to trust a tablet to respond to touch was a massive no-go for me.

I wanted to love this tablet.  It has such great potential.  I love the idea of it but it does have its flaws.  I found out it does not have the capability to pick up 5 GHz WiFi signal, only 2.4.  That's a bummer.  The screen looks like plastic, but I'm not sure, I was disappointed in that but after using it it does give a nice picture.  This thing was slow as molasses when I got it first set up.  It did hold a charge for about 6 hours.  It took 2 hrs 20 minutes to charge from 20 percent.  It took forever to download apps.  It was lagging a lot.  It was making me want to throw it against the wall.  I tried everything.  Went on YouTube and did the tricks to make tablets faster but nothing worked.  Found out not compatible with 5ghz.  Researched more on WiFi.  I went to my router page and changed some things around and read up on routers and realized that was my biggest flaw.  Updated my router, and changed the channel used and it became much better, not great but descent.  I realize now that living in condo and sharing channels with lots of people will slow you down.  Also I just don't have the fastest internet service if not using my 5ghz.  My router is getting to point where it could be called old.  I know this tablet could be faster with better WiFi.  Movies work fine, apps fine, some little slow to pull up, like amazon.  Any who I do love it and I found it at the price of 60 dollars so no complaints.  Absolutely love the hardware.  Love how it connects keyboard to tablet like a surface.  Overall I do love this tablet, just wish it could pick up 5ghz signal.

In order to save time, I'll list the pros and cons of purchasing this device:

Pros:
-Large screen
-Comes with a keyboard!
-Runs android, and easily connects to the internet
-Zero lag when running 7 games simultaneously

Cons:
-Comes with a surprising amount of preloaded software
-Not easy to root (I broke mine in an attempt to do so), thus preventing you from using things like Cyanogenmod
-Cheap-feeling plastic exterior
-Can't find recovery images ANYWHERE- you break it off of an insurance plan, you might as well buy a new one.
-Speakers are the worst ones I have heard on a tablet. Use a bluetooth speaker or headphones instead.

In all, the "Viking Pro" 10 inch tablet is a decent tablet, though low-end. It makes for a great burner device for school or a perfect gift to a child. For more intensive computing needs, get a higher-end tablet or a laptop.

I usually don't leave negative reviews - I'll put the energy into a review when I REALLY like something, but the activation energy for negative reviews is usually too high.  I just feel that I owe it to others to offer my warnings about this paperweight.

I thought I was being conscientious by going online and finding an independent review of the RCA tablet - the one I found (a vlog) was apparently done by someone on the take.

So, yes, you get what you pay for.  The reviews say that the sound system is poor - that is true, but it's about what you'd expect for a $100 tablet.  The video resolution is adequate if you aren't too worried about high def.

But this thing is  S  L  O  W  !  !  !
When I use it (because I'm too cheap to buy another one for at least a year after I spent $100 on this one), I turn it on and then put it down, pick up my phone, and play a word on Words with Friends.  After that, it might be ready to use.  Then I click on an icon, maybe my email.  Put it down, go to the kitchen to get some more ice in my drink, chat with one of my adults-living-at-home-children who happens to have arisen from the deep for a brief period, then go back to the tablet to see if the email app has launched yet.  Probably not, but I needed to pee anyway, so I go take care of that.  Speaking of which, if you use your tablet to distract you while you undertake more extended activities in the bathroom, forget about it, unless you opt to cut out all fiber and fluids to make those visits considerably longer.

On top of being slow, or maybe related to that issue, it freezes up for extended periods.  I might be in the middle of tapping out an email, and it will freeze for 221 seconds or so (I counted one of them this morning), then a message will pop up saying "Outlook app is not responding.... close it?  wait  ok".  If you are unfortunate enough to actually own one of these, I suggest selecting "wait".  You've got about 75% chance of it coming back to you with your partially completed email intact, so it's better than closing it out and having a 100% chance of losing it.  Oh, and forget about playing any type of game that has a time factor.

Sometime during the next 11 months I'll conveniently leave this thing somewhere for another poor sap to find, mysteriously having erased all connections to my personal accounts.  Then I'll do a bit more research before I buy a new tablet/pad.

Was not expecting iPad quality or features and wasn't disappointed. I just wanted an inexpensive tablet for viewing downloaded Netflix shows on the go or in bed. I've had to try sometimes as many as 5 tries before it with respond properly. Other times, I can touch it several times before it responds at all. I have had my tablet for several days and I love it! Be sure you get the 6.0 version. It is much faster and has more items in the store. I got mine at a local store for pickup the same day. You can run Microsoft products for free! You can download the apps and not use the cloud. Also you can print on a regular classic printer or print from the cloud. Nice to have a choice! I noticed someone complained that there is not the 360 hinge on this, which I think is a plus. I like this better. It gives you the option of using as a light weight tablet stand alone without the keyboard. I own a 360 device and I like this option better. Its very quick to switch to different position. You just remove, flip screen reverse and you are ready for tent mode, or stand mode, or tablet mode You get all the positions that you get from the 360 mode with the extra option to remove the keyboard. More flexibility. Nice while traveling by plane. Give it a try. I use mine more than the expensive 360 device. Sound is louder than my other device. Screen resolution the same. I can run more apps on this than my other device! A no brainer!

I actually have two of these that I got on Black Friday two years ago and I have to say that I am pretty darn impressed with them.  I use one mainly for heavier work; word processing, on-line sales, and the such.  The other is more my entertainment one, as I have been loading it with movies from flixster and vudu.
I had been concerned that I was running out of space on my movie one as I had both the built in memory and the 32 gig card full.  I had read conflicting reports about running a larger memory card, so I decided to give it a try.  I bought a sandisk 64gig card, powered off this tablet that I am using right now, popped out my old card and popped in the new and powered the tablet back on.  I then went to the settings menu, then storage, but it didn't see my new card.  I told it to mount and sd card, it saw the card but said that it was formatted wrong and asked me if I wanted to format it.  I told it to, the tablet formated the card, and promptly told me that I had successfully installed the sd card and that it had 59.4 gig of space available to use.  Where did the other 5 gig go?  Who knows.... but I am now going to see if I can get a 128 gig card and try it.  I expect that should work just fine also.  By the way... I am running Android 5.0.1 right now.  So this thing is bone stock.
  My only real complaints now are that my heavy lifter tablet is starting to have a fairly short battery life, 2-3 hr, but I have spent a lot of time using it while charging it and gotten it pretty hot several times, so that is more my fault.  That also probably explains why that one is slowing down some as well.... heat tends to kill the processor.  Again, my fault.  The other complaint.... when I go to use a real computer or laptop, I start trying to touch screen stuff all the time like I do with my Vikings!!!!  OOOPPPSSS!!!
  I also like the fact that it has a full size USB port, a micro USB port, a seperate charging port, and some goofy HDMI port that is kind of hard to find the cable for.....  But hey... it has bluetooth, will supposedly cast the screen, I have never tried, and hooks up well to my WIFI and is reasonably fast with not a lot of hangups in it.  I have dropped both of them multiple times, crammed them into backpacks and knocked them around, and basically not given either of my Vikings an easy life, and they are both still kicking.  So yeah.... I very much like and recommend them.

I just go my package and so far I'm really enjoying it! It's perfect for writing and working when I don't want to use my large laptop, it is able to use Microsoft word which is something I haven't found in a lot of other tablets and what sets this one apart for me. So glad I purchased this item.

Decent piece of equipment for the price.

Pros:
-Good resolution
-Clear sound (actually better than some laptops)
-Easy initial set up
-Connects/disconnects from keyboard easily
-Can use touchscreen while keyboard connected
-Has front/rear cameras
-Not heavy
-Sturdy build
-Easy to read keys
-Round power plug instead of micro UBS
-Will support additional 32GB SIM card
-Good battery life but would suggest keeping it plugged in if streaming video or online

Cons:
-When multiple apps/Windows are open there is no "close all" feature/icon
-Does NOT support all games/apps on our Samsung phones and Lenovo tablet
-All ports and power button on left side (not big issue for us but may be for others)
-Volume control on keyboard only (it is possible to adjust on tablet when they're separated)
-Hyper sensitive finger pad that if brushed by anything may change what you're doing (got used to it quickly to avoid issues)
-Came with space taking Wal-Mart and Sam's Club apps (we deleted them)
-Wouldn't suggest giving this to children under 8 years of age (make sure child is aware of product and uses common sense when detaching keyboard)
-On/Off button is small and it takes a couple seconds to power on
-No % power battery display, battery icon only
-Camera is 2 megapixels (don't use it, so no biggie for us)

We ordered this because the micro USB power port in the Lenovo Yoga tablet became loose and wouldn't charge. We kept having to push it in and put weight on one end in order to charge it. Was very pleased to come across this tablet. The power supply, Android friendly, size and price were the selling points. We use it for entertainment only like Netflix, YouTube and a few game apps. We were very disappointed to find out that we couldn't download some apps that we use frequently. Regardless, it's a nice tablet for the price and we'll be keeping it. Nice to see RCA still making products.

**DO YOUR HOMEWORK IF YOU PLAN TO DOWNLOAD APPS!!!
great I love it

Great for movies, internet. I do not care for the keyboard. It falls off and some keys are in odd places, not qwerty. But you can type o it in a pinch. I use it more as a touchscreen tablet and leave the keyboard off. Could use a stand for movies, and a longer power cord.

My one issue is that 1 of the tablets was manufactured 2015 while the other 2 were 2016. No big deal, except that the 2015 one has a few quirks.. Like certain games that work on the 2016s, say incompatible on the 2015. And while the 2016s are running Android 6.0, the 2015 is on Android 5.0

It's slightly frustrating, but not enough for me to scream about. As I said, so far - they work and the kids are happy.

But for now, I'm TOTALLY satisfied!

I bought two of these and paid $75.00 each.  One for my daughter and one for me.  It was our first tablet purchase so we didn't want to spend a lot of money.  My daughter's works great and is a good basic tablet.  Mine is slow to start up and sluggish at best on internet sites.  We both live in the same house so use the same wifi connection.  I like the design and the ease of use on this tablet but I think I got the "slow one" and my daughter got the better one.  Since we only paid $75.00 for them I can't complain.  Now mine is having trouble charging.  I have to jiggle the power line to get it to stay in the tablet.  Then it charges pretty slowly.  I'm sure I am not getting a good connection.  I don't use the keyboard at all like I thought I would.  I usually am using this table when I'm in bed at night so the keyboard is not very comfortable to use lying in bed.  We purchased a different cover to allow the table to prop up, it won't do that with the keyboard on it because the little "leg" that is attached to the cover is pretty weak.  You only get one angle with the little leg too.  All in all this is a great learner tablet for two novices.  I'm 68 and my daughter 49.  We mostly use our laptops for the internet but I have enjoyed having a tablet at night to browse the internet.  I like the 10 inch size because I like browsing decorating sites.  Smaller tablet would not give me as big a picture.  So if you are looking for a good beginner tablet I would recommend this but next time I am going to upgrade.  And as a side note my daughter is not having a problem with the charge connection.  Hers is fine, it's just mine.  Must be a manufacturing defect of some sort.
Awesome. It is cheap and good for games and YouTube

Great little tablet and hold a good charge.  You can set up 2 profiles so we can both use it, easy to download wifi printer. Does everything and more than my Chromebook.  Price was excellent, so I can travel with it and not go nuts if something happens to it.

Very difficult to set up.  Asks for Google account information; not just your Google email, but your name (not password) to verify your account.  Which didn't work, despite retrying several times.  Don't try to tab between fields here, "tab" means go to next page.  The keyboard has a touchpad, which is nice, but the click action of the touch pad is way too sensitive.  Try to move your cursor and it thinks you've clicked.  It forces you to sign in to a Google account; I have several, and it kept saying "There's no Google Account with the information you provided".  I double checked my name spelling on every account (never know, maybe I did "Mike" instead of "Michael")... no joy.  Had to create a new account, what a waste.

Set up is REALLY LENGTHY.  Don't expect to be using this notebook quickly.  It wants you to answer myriad questions, agree or decline various invasive and privacy-unfriendly options, etc. before it actually lets you use the tablet.

Eventually it got to the point where it kept asking over and over again  if I wanted to add any more email addresses.  I kept clicking "Not now" and it would come back to the same screen, asking me to add more email addresses.  Boy, they really want me to give them my email addresses! You can't seem to get past this screen.  I finally turned it off.  Maybe I'll try again tomorrow, or maybe I'll just return it.

love Love LOVE my little laptop-looking tablet! Everyone that sees it, wants it. No one believes it was such a bargain! The only issue i have is the not-so-great speaker, but an external, bluetooth speaker does the trick. I don't need eardrum bustin' bass or 'fingernails on the chalkboard' treble anyhow, just enough volume to Facetime or hear a movie/watch tv from my app's.

As with any computer/IT device, much depends on the internet service you use. For surfing the web, my little Viking Pro tablet just zips right along! But even when it's offline, it handles all the apps I have installed with no problem. I have a good anti-virus that also cleans up needless files, etc. to make sure it runs smoothly.

The only other issue I have is that I like to listen to sleep/meditation tones when I go to bed, but there is no customizable timer for the display. It's either 10 mins, 15 minutes or 30 minutes, and the display goes off and shuts down whichever app I'm running.

Still and all, would I recommend? Youbetcha!

It's not that it doesn't work, but it's slower than my 3 year old Samsung Galaxy Tab on KitKat that I wanted to replace after dropping it and smashing the screen.
The apps take a LONG time to open, and then when you want to go back and view the home screen it takes a good 20 seconds before the apps on the screen show up.
Don't try using the tablet while it's charging via mini-usb either. If you do, the screen has a mind of its own. Typing words creates a bunch of spaced gibberish and backspace or highlighting won't delete. It charges, but that's about it.  Possibly the reason it comes with an old fashioned charger.
Even now as I type this on the tablet itself the volume display keeps opening and closing even though I'm nowhere near the volume buttons on the keyboard or the display and I'm not even charging it. It's a buggy/defective UI. Typing this with the awesome (but small) keyboard and the cursor keeps jumping up to lines I typed above.

I love the keyboard and magnetic attachment to the tablet. I love that the tablet goes into a 'desktop mode' when attached and that there's a 'mouse' like part on the keyboard.

For $109 the display is adequate without being bright, but it's good enough I suppose.

Battery life - I really can't comment. It came fully charged and drained by the end of setup and downloading from backups. I've recharged it, but so buggy I don't think I'll give it a chance to discharge again.
I've had a lot of android devices and none have ever behaved so poorly... especially a newer one (2016 model?!?!).  I'm happy I purchased from Amazon as I'll be returning the product and the extra warranty I purchased.  I'll spend the extra few $ and get something of a better brand/quality.

Seems they put more thought into the keyboard than the tablet.

Few other things to note - the entire thing is plastic. The tablet is light.. it's nice that it has premiums that Ihave never seen on other tablets like all the ports for HDMI, USB, SD Card etc and ability to connect a mouse. Also like that you can choose SD as your default storage space.  Still - just can't deal with the buggy OS.

Bluetooth is another problem. Fine for music, but for video the lag between the picture and when the audio actually gets to your ears is about 1-2 seconds delayed. Worse than watching an overdubbed karate movie by far.  I use the same bluetooth headphones with other tabs/phones and pc and don't have a noticeable delay, so it's definitely the tab.

During the writing of this review the screen automatically shrunk down this app multiple times now, and the aformentioned volume pop-ups. Also, no type correction options popped up, even using google keyboard.

Hope this was helpful to folks making their decision.

Let me know if you have questions.

It's not all sunshine and rose however as I have a found a few cons to go with all those pros.mostly in that there are some apps that I was using on my Dell Venu 3 3830 tablet that according to the Google PLay store are "not compatible with this device."  No explanation why despite the fact that the Dell while it had similar tech specs only had 16GB onboard memory and was only running Kit Kat 4.4.2. I know its not the Lollipop because I have these same apps on my Note 3 which also runs Lollipop. Now the Note has 3GB of ram but the Dell like the RCA only has 1GB yet it ran these various apps. This is handy 10" tablet with detachable keyboard and is great as an auxiliary computer for travelling or bringing to the library to write term papers.  The battery time is probably about five hours while typing out a word document, but best to keep the charger with you so it doesn't run out.  With 32Gb, that is more than adequate for most light work and apps; adding a micro SD card adds additional memory for storage of photos, documents, music, etc.  YouTube videos play adequately, though you may have to add a speaker or have earphones.  With Chromecast, YouTube videos can be watched on the TV.  The built in speakers are very low and that seems questionable.  The keyboard takes some getting used to; it seems too delicate with the cursor ready to move at the slightest provocation to the wrong spot.  It is a detachable 10" tablet with front and rear 2 Mp cameras.  While not adequate for taking distance photos, more than adequate for taking close-up photos of friends and relations.  The HDMI is a micro-HDMI so an adapter has to be purchased.  The computer works with a mouse, I use a wireless mouse because the computer touch pad seems just too delicate.  The Google photo app has tremendous flexibility for cropping photos, adding light or shade, etc.  The OS is Android 5.0 Lollipop which to my way of thinking is simply stupendous.  It will automatically connect and sync with your phone.  For those of us who are a certain mature age, the Android OS lends simplicity to what oftentimes appears daunting.  In other words, you have nothing to do but sit back and let the OS do its thing.  The machine comes with Google docs, Microsoft Word has to be added.  My preference is for Microsoft Word because I write in several languages and need to have that flexibility on my computer; while you can put Microsoft Word on this computer, I don't know whether language pacts can be placed on it for ease of writing as it can on a Windows.  (Apparently Google Play has language apps.)  The product also has a function where a person can write on the screen (with a stylus, sold separately) which is handy for taking notes in algebra, chemistry, etc.

So as an auxiliary computer for when a person has to be away form the home computer, this is a great adjunct.

My review begins and stops with the charger. It operates only 110 Volts. One must carry a voltage converter to use this tablet in many, if not most other countries when traveling. The specs listed on the Amazon site do not include the charger's voltage rating. Amazon is lacking in this category for many of its products one might use when traveling abroad. What company in this century makes products such as tablets, shavers, laptops and smart phones with chargers that do not operate on universal current? RCA does.

I bought this tablet based on reviews and abilities. I needed something bigger than my phone and more portable than my PC. After a week, I am very happy with the performance of the machine so far, including that it keeps cool while streaming videos in keyboard or non keyboard mode.

Pros:
So far, works as advertised. Fast and smooth. Screen is great for a tablet for around $100.
- USB Port
- Micro USB slot
- Micro SD Card slot (I added a 64gb Samsung)

Cons:
-Initial charge period might make you think it is DOA. Give it at least 1 or 2 hours before you have enough charge to turn it on. I personally freaked out, as I am used to electronics of this type, or anything requiring a charge have enough to "turn it on" out of the box, however this was not the case. But, after a full hour, I had enough charge to turn it on and get it set up. Turned off, it took about 8 hours or more to initially get to full charge (I am sure most of these Viking Pro 10's are mass produced and not sold at their original price point, so they have been in a warehouse somewhere)
-Charging in general. The supplied charger can get hot during charge. It's a plug, not a micro USB.
- Mine has a weird habit of opening the camera from the lock screen. Annoying and I am sure partly my fault.
- Semi- "Con" ... the casing is semi cheap plastic. So I recommend some kind of case for it. The keyboard plastic is iffy, so we will see.

The main reason for buying this was to see if I would use it enough to go with a bigger brand name. I might not if this lasts. For about $110 to 120, including keyboard, so far I believe this to be an incredible deal as long as you are not rough on it.
For those worried about size of the keyboard, please remember this is a 10 inch screen, so you get a comparably sized keyboard, it is going to be small. Big fingers won't be happy, but medium sized ok. And the mouse cursor is ok, maybe a little sensitive, but I haven't tried to change that setting yet.
Overall a solid buy for the price so far.
Track pad is not that responsive, mouse button in track pad doesn't click well. Good tablet, low quality laptop though

If you want to hook this up to a pc or something else to transfer pictures or video files forget it, it doesn't work, according to RCA the micro usb port is for charging only which btw is really poor I had it on charge through usb playing a game and it actually went down.

It should specify that you can not move files from this device to another device through micro usb thats actually a noob thing to do even the $35 cheaper and nasty tablets let you do that.

I did not buy this here. I got a better deal at Walmart for $80 dollars. The screen is a very good looking IPS screen and it shows. The viewing angles are very good. Video worked very good for this. I used the youtube app and I did watch some videos using chrome. Both worked fine.

I did play games on this tablet. I played Pinball Arcade and that played and looked great. I also played reckless racing. I have also played Zaccaria Pinball on this and again very positive for that use. Getting over 40fps to 50 frames per second. I have also played Trial Frontiers and no issues it ran great.  I had no issues playing these games. The speaker is not great. It does work. However its a single speaker. However you could turn on the bluetooth and use external speakers or headphones. The keyboard has some weight to it. The tablet feels a little flimsy when you hold it. So I have played around with this for a little bit more. The mouse pad works good its a lot on the small size along with the keyboard. It does work good.

The weight of this Tablet is light although holding it for a long time might wear our your arm. Not an issue if your using the keyboard. The power cord it comes with is a little short however this can be fixed by buying an extension cord.

Also just one other point the keyboard does have a volume control so you can control it without having to touch the tablet. Along with brightness and other features. Still enjoying the tablet. Just a few more thoughts. The keyboard will some times get disconnected from the tablet. Even though it is still on keyboard.  I have had to reseat the tablet again and it picks up the keyboard again. The wifi is also another plus its very powerful. Great signal. Also its lightweight. The battery life is around 5 hours or so depends if you watch online videos or not. So if your into games and looking for a cheap tablet that is up to date on android get this puppy. Still very happy.

All together, though, I'm very happy with my purchase.

Our portable RCA DVD player broke after years of use and abuse by our children. I decided I would replace it with a tablet instead.  Tablets are super cheap now and actually cost about the same as a portable DVD player, except that they have wifi, apps, games, touch-screens and more.  The only drawback to this plan was that I knew I would have to buy a good sized SD card to go with it so I could put a few movies on it for when we don't have wifi...  In the long run this downfall had some major updrafts to more than compensate for the time and money spent converting DVD video to be viewed on Android tablet.  The benefit was space!  No DVDs to have to carry around, get lost, scratched, etc.
I will likely never buy a portable DVD player again,  modern technology is bulldozing over and replacing yet another piece of equipment... in a good way.  If you don't already have a program for converting video and media files, I highly recommend "Any Video Converter."  just the free version will do really.

I almost knocked off 1 star, but then I decided to leave it 5 stars.  The quality of the image is not the greatest, but you know what?... I knew it was not going to be an Apple or Samsung tablet going in and didn't expect much beyond simple quality, enough to replace a portable DVD player.  The screen image is as good if not better than portable players of its size... so it lives up to my expectations and beyond.  It runs apps and games quite smoothly too, almost as good as my Galaxy S5.  Here's to hoping it lasts several years like my past RCA portable DVD player.

A fantastic Tablet. I wanted a replacement for my Kindle Fire because I mainly want a tablet to watch YouTube. Since Amazon doesn't have an official YouTube App, this seemed like a good replacement. (I got mine at Walmart though, as it was on sale for $80 there)

The tablet is small, lightweight, easy to use, and great for what you pay for. I've played around with more than a few budget Android tablets and have been somewhat disappointed for the most part due to clunkyness, bad performance, of lack of support for popular apps. This tablet works great. All system animations are smooth. Setup is easy. The keyboard dock is superb, it easily sits in place without pulling or snapping it in or out. All the ports (USB, micro USB, HDMI, and and SD Card slot) are a great plus, and the tablet can charge off either micro USB or it's proprietary wall charger. While I wish the keyboard dock itself had a charging port built into it, it's a small nit-pick compared to how great the device is otherwise.

The only thing this tablet lacked from the get-go was that my Kindle Fire had is access to Amazon Underground apps. But after installing the Underground app, that is no longer a problem. It was a great upgrade for me.

Amazing product given the price: a small laptop and a detached 10" pad. Decent google Android 5.0 Android system; clean (no uninstallable apps). Other brands like Samsong, LG, Motorola, all have apps that I can not uninstall. This is a clean Google android 5.0, prefect--light and fast.

Good quality of the materials made for the device: solid and responsive. The keyboard is USB attached through a special pin. This keyboard is much more responsive than the bluetooth keyboard which is connected through a wireless bluetooth.

I bought it for myself. My daughter likes it and I gave to her because I think a bigger device at home would preserve her eyesight better than a a 5.5" cell phone screen. I am thinking to buy another one for myself.

My wife gave me a Viking Pro for Christmas. I thought you would be interested in my experience with the device.

First the keyboard is not compatible with the tablet. Pressing a key gives unknown results on the tablet. For example pressing the shift key inserts a heading.

Pressing a key on the tablet also sometimes results in a different character than the one pressed showing up on the screen. It is necessary for some letters to hunt around for the correct spot to press.

Sometimes an app will not open upon a tap. Several taps can be necessary. I have had  another app open other than the one I have selected.

I have been scrolling down through an app and have the app close and another one open.

I have had the whole thing freeze up. A reboot is the only way out.

The speaker is very poor quality. It is not fun listening to music with the speaker, I use earphones.

The camera takes good distance pictures but the selfi mode gives nothing but a blur.

Now for the most unusual problem I have ever seen. I cannot get access to an account requiring user name and password. There is something different about the characters in the password. I get the error password and user name do not match. I wanted to use Netflicks so I created a new account with username and password on the tablet. This gave me access. Only to find out the Netflix app does not work. It gives a great picture (I like the screen size) but the audio was terrible. I have played movies from the USB port and they work fine.

I put the keyboard in the trash, put some free games on the tablet and gave it to my grandson. He is very happy with the device.

I bought this product primarily for a one month trip to Spain. The mini-usb port allows for easy DC connection while using google maps (offline). I bought it also for its hdmi port which allowed me to connect to Netflix via TV... excellent clarity even with low bandwidth. Of course, the flexibility of a two-in-one speaks for itself. The screen size is just right for my purposes. The full usb port works with a mouse and flash drives. The speed along with lollipop is excellent and has yet to freeze. Some have complained about the keyboard, but all the functions on mine work flawlessly. It may be the version of 5.0, but there is no switch function for which camera side to view. If someone has figured that out, please  let me know. Although it could be my VPN service working with google, I couldn't get it to work... Otherwise, what a great product at a great price! Thank you, RCA.

Being a touch screen and having a keyboard makes it great and my little guy loves starfall and ABCmouse.com apps. He happily learns while he thinks he playing games.
It take a bit to turn on at first, but that's only if you turn it off completely. Sleep mode it wakes up really quickly. Still working on different apps and can't find a compatible app to stream Amazon Prime movies/TV shows through google play, so that's a bummer, and can't buy apps through amazon for what I've found. Picture quality is horrible, but hey, I have a phone to take pictures and videos, so no big deal. But overall, I love this little tablet. Way better for the price than the ipad or Samsung galaxy!

If you're searching for an equivalent to a Samsung or Apple Tablet, continue your search. This tablet is in the category of the Kindle Fire. It's a low end tablet, however a darn good one for about $100. Some people have commented that it could be made of better quality, etc. Again, this is a $100 tablet, not a $600 tablet. You get what you pay for-usually. This tablet exceeds the price tag and I'll tell you why....

-Very functional
-Well built for the price (not the most aesthetically pleasing, but it's hard to screw up the look of a tablet)
-Good picture quality for the price
-The touch screen is not clunky at all. It's very responsive.
-This is basically an Android Phone without the phone (If you know Android, the OS is the same thing here)
-The keyboard is very responsive and built surprisingly well.
-Keyboard disengages from tablet very easily. No locking mechanism. It just slides in and out.

On to the reasons why it's $100.....

-Sound quality is poor. It's not muffled, it's just very low. You'll find yourself checking early on to make sure it's up all the way. You'll then realize the sound is just utterly low and not great quality.
-It takes an oddly long time to boot up. I'm not sure why, but I thought it froze on a few instances. Be patient with it.
-Not the most attractive looking tablet.
-Not recommended for replacement of a real laptop/computer. I feel that the keyboard while built very well is rather obsolete because it doesn't function well as a computer. This device is best used as a inexpensive tablet replacement.
-The camera is dreadful. You'll get the same image quality out of a baked potato. Horrible!

Otherwise, this is a really good tablet w/keyboard for the price. It's hard to knock this at the price truthfully. Again, just don't complain when you're not getting iPad quality. Hello.....look at the price. If you want just a simple tablet to play games on, watch some Youtube, check mail and do some general browsing, this is a great buy. If you are looking for a main source as a computer, I urge you to pony up a few more hundred dollars on a low end laptop or just get a higher end tablet. I hope this helps.
The perfect size

I got one delivered Christmas eve, and while rather different (first time working with an android 'laptop') it is good. A delightful replacement for the latest generation Fire 7inch HD I am giving away to my brother, which annoys me immensely. NOTE: one speaker, sound level is modest. The virtual-mouse 'scratch pad' area is too fast for comfort and cannot be adjusted in this generation of Android- an update for the driver could sure help on this! It works fine with a wireless Argus mouse however.

Received as a gift for Christmas. I've been setting up various Android devices over the past few days for friends and family members and this is the first one that gave me a runaround. Don't sign in to Google when you first start up the tablet or the Play Store will not let you update apps. Wait until after finishing setup and then open the Play Store and sign in from there.

This is not a lightning fast tablet. It does slow up a bit during normal use and videos aren't butter smooth, but are watchable.

The keyboard is cramped for a right-handed typer like me (right shift is tiny but left shift is large. I wish they would get rid of the ".com" button and make the right shift larger.

I'm typing this review from the tablet now. Arrived at 99% battery but I let it sit on the charger for an extra hour just because. Two hours of continuous use and updating apps and downloading more apps over Wi-Fi and it was down to 74%. I'll post an update to this later because it is about to spend four days out of town with me and I plan to use an HDMI cable to watch Netflix on the hotel TV so I can see how long it'll run doing that.

In the meantiime I'm excited to have something light and compact to replace an eight pound Acer gaming laptop I've been using while traveling that also has a bad screen cable and I must bring a monitor to use it.

I'll also update the review to let you all know how well an external mouse and keyboard work.
My son is happy with my purchasing this item for him and he is able to watch videos and movies without slow movement unlike the 2 Irulu i purchased.

I've used many tablets over the years including the fruity one and Samsung's and while there products are good, they are in MHO, somewhat expensive, for most people. This tablet, for my use,..surfing the web and streaming music via BT is incredible!! Its fast with a very nice screen and excellent battery life. Seriously, for the money, it can't be beat. I don't use the keyboard alot but it also works well!!

First of all, let me comment that I often receive free items to review from Amazon to review.  This is NOT one of them; I decided to spend my own cash on this device, so be assured it is a genuinely unbiased review (I did get it as a Black Friday deal at a major retailer, but paid almost as much as the normal Amazon price).

I have a long history with tablets.  My last Android tablet was an Asus Transformer TF300, which as of late 2015 still sells USED for double what a new Viking Pro costs.  I indeed sold my old Asus because it performed horribly, even after fully factory resetting the darned thing.  The screen was gorgeous, and it felt great, but it just was not usable.  On to my review of the Viking Pro ("Pros and Cons").

PROS
- The screen looks great; I was afraid the viewing angles would be bad (as many other cheap tablets are), but the screen looks fantastic from any angle.
- Expandable with a micro SD card slot.
- Blazing fast snappy performance; beats the pants off my Asus Transformer.
- Sound is decent for a tablet.
- Has all the ports you do need, and none that you don't (has mini HDMI, micro USB for charging, etc).
- Has physical volume up and down buttons.
- Comes with a keyboard (probably won't get much use from me, but it works seamlessly)
- The price for what you get is unbelievable.
- Runs every piece of software I can throw at it, including very power hungry apps like pinball games, Baldur's Gate, Temple Run series, etc.

CONS
- Plastic construction doesn't "feel" as good as my old Asus (or an iPad, for example).

In summary, this is an incredibly wonderful tablet that competes with tablets that are more than double in price.  It does everything I need it to do, and is truly the best performance bargain in the tablet world at this time (as of late 2015).  Highly recommended!

For the price, this tablet is OK. It could be better. It could've been made of better material. It's super light-weight. It's definitely made of cheap plastic. The touch screen feels, looks cheap and scratches easily. The screen resolution is acceptable for such a cheap tablet. I think this tablet is a good starter for newbies who are looking to get into the tablet market.

I bought this at Walmart for $79.99  I have to say that for the price I cant complain. The keyboard is solid and works great. The tablet is lightweight and built very cheap, plastic case, but it delivers. I would recommend spending a few bucks more and getting something better. I ended up buying another Tablet after this. I bought the Visual Land 10" Prestige with keyboard and case for $149.99 from HSN. It's twice the tablet but twice the price. It also has Octa core which is very sweet. The bottom line folks is you get what you pay for!

Its nice. Big screen. The volume is low on it, even at it's highest.

Things I've found out so far:
* MicroSD card slot: Supports up to 128GB. Cards must be in the FAT32 format for the tablet to recognize the contents. Android 5.0, the tablet's OS, can format one in the FAT32 format.
* USB 2.0 port: Same story as the microSD card slot--up to 128GB, must be in FAT32.
* No direct file transfer with Windows systems via microUSB connection. Workaround: WiFi file transfer apps are fast (and spare a USB port on your desk/laptop).
* ~5% power drop over ~12 hours when in the sleep mode (via either screen timeout or short-pressing the power button). Note: Wi-Fi and Bluetooth off, sync off, all apps are closed.
* Cameras: 2MP in the back (just OK) and 1MP in the front (barely serviceable)
* Speaker? There is one, but then better use Bluetooth or the headphone port.
* Keyboard: Cramped and temperamental, but serviceable with practice. Standouts: camera figure for screenshot (not camera); screen off long for power off, short for sleep mode (not sure yet).
* Touch pad: Temperamental but serviceable, right-click for the back function.

It was for my dad as a christmas gift and it came earlier than expected (with manual and in a box) so thumbs up!

I had just some problems dealing with the language program because it had Korean as language setting but not for the keyboard settings (how funny) so I had to buy it in the google play that would actually work.

So far, so good.  Whether this tablet can replace my laptop remains to be seen, but my primary reason for purchasing this tablet was to have a device for the purpose of productivity that can be used as a strictly Wi-Fi access device.  The Google Play store offers Microsoft Word as an app, so have downloaded it.  The tablet started up quickly upon first power-up and has down a firmware update without incident.  Still not sure about the cameras; may need an area or time of day with more light before I can be sure of taking photos on the device - images were a bit murky.

For the price, however, not bad at all.  Keyboard a tad cramped for my fingers, but still getting used to it.  I actually paid less for this item than I would have at Walmart, and as I got it through Amazon, I'm more certain of the quality.

The RCA 10" tablet is not a good tablet to purchase. It has a cheep plastic case and a plastic, not glass, screen. The screen quality is OK straight on but poor at an angle. With only one gig system memory it is slow at multitasking. It seems that quality control is lacking because the unit I bought failed to have a functioning on-screen keyboard. The attached keyboard worked fine, but one needs an on-screen keyboard to use it as a tablet! The output of  the speaker is poor. Thus, I returned it. I am disappointed that RCA put their name on this tablet. I would suggest, if you are looking for a tablet, shop for something else.

I wanted something smaller than a laptop for traveling, this seems to be a good size. Even though keyboard will detach, if has the laptop like property of being able to adjust the angle of screen and it staying place. I don't use any computer for games so I don't know about that, but it runs My Sword for Android (Bible app) wonderfully, heavily use Facebook (in Opera browser) and instagram. Has more volume than my laptops. Opera seems faster than Chrome. For $79 Black special I am delighted.

While this tablet isn't perfect, it's a really good one. From reviews I've seen, there are so many who claim that it slows down when it updates. That hasn't happened for me, and it's already updated. While the keyboard is something to get used to, since it's a smaller thing to use, it works rather well.  Contrary to what other people say, I've found that my tablet does connect to a Windows laptop via the usb. It connects like any other usb device that runs android and allows me to look at and make modifications to what is already on the tablet. The speakers are not the best, but with either headphones or a cheaper bluetooth speaker, you'll be just fine. Overall, this is really a good buy! Anyone wanting a small "laptop" feel would be good getting this. It's perfect for taking notes in class as well!

I bought this tablet for my daughter's 50th birthday less than a week ago.  I got it from a discount center but I'm looking for another one for my husband for Christmas.  The price was great and my daughter has stated that "it was the best birthday present she's ever received".  I'm the computer person in my family in that I keep our ancient computers running.  This tablet does everything with ease, has a large enough screen so you're not straining to see it and the detachable keyboard is an added plus, at the same time, you also have the touch screen.  My daughter lives next door to us in a mobile home (60 ft away) on our acreage and she easily picks up the internet from the router in our house with this tablet.  As I said, I love this tablet & expect to buy another for my husband and maybe sneak one in for me too down the road, lol.

Overall, it's a very nice tablet and highly recommended.
great tablet for the wife

Have had this tablet for about 5 months now and I love it!! Its not the fastest tablet but once you have been on it for a couple minutes it speeds up. I gave my Kindle fire away and replaced it with this product because of the android operating system it has. I was able to download more apps than the fire and the pictures, I would say are the same. I couldn't beat the price and like I said earlier if you like the android operating system don't look any further. I only have one knock on the tablet and that's the sound speaker it comes with. Its not the clearest but I used headphones with it so it doesn't matter.

If you're like most people, you have a laptop for the resource-intensive tasks (work, school, etc.) and a cell phone for the on-the-go tasks (calls, messaging, games, etc.). A tablet is usually positioned somewhere in the middle for things that don't need a high-end processor, yet require a screen bigger than a phone, for things like streaming, e-book, surfing, etc. A lot of people turn to high-end devices like iPads or Galaxy Tabs, but I ask, why?  Processing power already comes with the laptop, and  you already get mobility with your phone. So there really is no need to pay premium pricing for  tablets. Hence budget models like the RCA Viking Pro fill a very important niche: for people who just need it for entertainment  (movies, social media, email) and other escapist activities.  At $80, this is one of the cheapest ways to fill in the gap, so I can watch Netflix, shop on Amazon and play Android games. And the addition of the keyboard is handy on the few times I do actual work on it, either quick Google docs, answering emails or making reservations. I did take away 1 star because you do get what you pay for. But what you get is still a lot.
